preface.title: Preface
preface.para:
This is much of my life's work regarding the non-Jew in
Torah
from my own personal study. I would like to share with everyone what I've found. These answers were received from my sojourn in Torah. I think many of us ask questions yet many of us get bogged down and never find definitive answers, which demoralize many of us to the point of giving up or disbelief. I like to think this book will convey the things I found that I believe are incumbent on every human-being to know. It would be a personal tragedy if I did not convey it for posterity.

I will use Hebrew words and phrases to help convey the original wisdom in context. Any translations into English are my own unless stated otherwise. Transliterated words will be italicised. I try to use only original Torah words, but when I deviate, it will most likely be due to problems in English words and their understanding that I need to rectify. Translated words from their original Hebrew often come out as vulgar. I do my best to not be common in my language. There is a balance that must be met between stooping language down for the simple man to understand and between giving the unadulterated wisdom. I think that balance is to use transliterated Hebrew nouns at the very least. If you're reading this book, then that means you must have the aptitude to learn new ideas and new words. We then might as well learn actual Hebrew words in context, rather than a translation that usually bastardizes the original meaning and wisdom of the word and any other negative side-effects a non-Hebrew language would do to describe Hebraic ideas and concepts.

For most of the book, I'll be using the term bnei Yisrael which is the Hebrew translation for children of Israel. It's common today to refer to bnei Yisrael as "Jews" or the Jewish People, but for the sake of clarity, I'll be using bnei Yisrael instead, which is usually the phrase used in Torah.

This book will not be received well by many people, including rabbis. They will disagree with the book, but be unable to give a clear proof why, or at the least, give straw-man arguments. An example, would be arguing I'm wrong about the attributes I give to the word bnei Noach, when really, the arguer is referring to goyim. Unfortunately for them and their listeners, bnei Noach and goyim are two different gedarim/categories of non-Jews. It's comparing apples and oranges as explained later in the book. Many do not understand the gedarim of non-Jews within Torah and it leads many astray and has caused much contention in the world. This book helps to rectify that. If I give my opinion about a matter, I usually preface the statement with "It appears to me" or "In my opinion". I also ask questions that I would like to know answers to. Please contact me through email.

This book is organic and being updated regularly. Instead of having a number of editions, I will be using a version number, similar to that of computer software and only use numbered editions when printing. The source files for the book are housed in a version controlled repository that is constantly being added to, updated, fixed and processed into multiple media formats.
